content: hello everyone why lock here with
something interesting for you this week the tabletop crafters guild masters have
partnered with Mantic games to talk about terrain crate these are sets of
assorted dungeons scatter terrain if you haven't heard of Mantic games they make
tons of awesome games including one of my favorites which is kings of war go
and check out their website now anyway they sent me a box and I was curious as
to how I could integrate this into my crafting so let's go open it up first
impressions I like the box colorful like it dungeon depths is the set we're
looking at today but there are others so I'll get the cellophane off of this
thing and crack it open inside there's a couple of trays that house all the
pieces in first impression they're solid they don't bend or anything they're
plastic they appear to have a lot of detail here's a bag with tons of the
really tiny bits I figured I'd lay these all out so you guys could get a full fly
through I'll go nice and slow this is every single piece that comes in the kit
dungeon traps wood logs great some it's a very good variety this is plastic the
detail is on par with what I've seen from other major shops so I am excited
to see how they paint up and on that note why don't we get to it
all right here we go gonna take some retributive armor this is a Games
Workshop paint into the airbrush and gonna tackle one of these treasure piles
just directly on there not gonna prime it I almost never prime my miniatures
and I've never had any issues this is plastic so I'm not gonna prime it either
so gold directly on there that's a good start so now we're gonna shade it I'm
gonna use right Glen flesh shade and just give it a fairly healthy coat one
thing I've learned in the past year or so is not to be shy when applying shade
it dries so much subtler than when you apply it so you just got to trust that
if you get short on it you don't get the right contrast to get staining so it's
easy to use a shade wrong in my experience so here I've actually been
doing two pieces at once about an hour later the shading has dried nice antique
look to it last thing I'm gonna do is dry brush this I'm going to use
Liberator gold work most of it off back on the palette and then dry brush
and instantly it looks amazing now this this was my litmus test this is why I
did these first I really wanted to gauge how good the detail was on these things
a treasure pile has a lot of pronounced detail and if anything was going to show
it off its these so awesome I'll finish those later
now when going through all this stuff I thought to myself a lot of these bits
would be great as clip-on features or like a shortcut so let's do that first
we'll make up the clip on blank we've done this many times in the past on the
channel but for completeness I'll blast through it real quick get a chunk of
double corrugated cardboard and then take some chipboard
this is graphics medium chipboard see the link in the description for my
affiliate link it's a easy totally free way to support the channel if you like
anyway cut two slabs of chipboard and these need to be 1/2 inch longer than
the centerpiece in one direction and hot glue them on like this so you have a
half inch long clip on one side and then with some cereal box or either cardstock
just hot glue it to cover that corrugation
painted solid black just cheap acrylic
craft paint then with a bit of kitchen sponge dab on some dark gray bleed off
most of the paint under the paper to get a fine stone like speckle then with a
lighter gray sponge on a little more so that's our standard clip on blank to
which we can attach whatever feature we like so this looks like a trap square of
some kind I envisioned it as a panel that's opened in the wall and poison
darts are flying out so I'm gonna base it with some standard gray then give it
a wash with black this is army painter dark tone but GW non-oil would work
anything any black wash and when that's totally dry we're gonna do a quick dry
brush with a light gray easy then I'll paint the recess with plain black and
finally some green for those dark tips then I just hot glued it on to the clip
on blank and this was a nice piece it looks like a mirror or a picture frame
so I baste it with a shimmering metallic silver then did the same gold recipe we
did earlier retributive armor Reglan flesh shade liberator gold and
again hot glue it to the clip on another piece that intrigued me was this
banner but rather than do it as a clip-on I wanted to be able to place it
like in the center of the room freestanding so one inch washer trace it
onto some cereal box or other cardstock and then super glue them together hot
glue is not very effective on smooth metals so I used super glue chopped a
length of kabob skewer and super glue that to the banner
again hot glue is not very effective here on the smooth plastic and then just
some random bead to help holster the post when a hot glue that to the base
and then fill it with hot glue and stick the post into it I wanted to do a nice
gradient on the banner so to the airbrush this is a light blue I'm gonna
do a solid base coat just two light passes for a smooth finish the second
color is a deep blue but since this is a large area I did an intermediate step
which was a 50/50 mix of the two colors sprayed the bottom two-thirds of the
banner and then finally with the deep blue only I sprayed the bottom third
since I'm not really an artist I didn't want to try to freehand the contents of
the banner I have these leftover Eldar transfer sheets which have great arcane
looking symbols on them so I picked one cut it out with a sharp knife submerge
in water for a couple minutes and prepared the surface of the banner with
a mixture of varnish and water and then while that's still wet slide the decal
on to it dab off the excess moisture and finish with a light application of more
varnish then I finished painting the thing but I'll spare you those steps
it's nothing new and we're about to go to the table to look at the finished
product but real quick some reminders there's a link in the description below
for my storefront has all the tools and supplies that I recommend and for all
you 3d printers out there while ochs crafting goods is sponsored by Heroes
hoard which has an excellent range of high quality models including but not
limited to all true tiles lines which are open Lock compatible
also check out my modules over on the DMS guild and remember $3 patrons get
free copies of all my releases alright if these tiles and clip-ons intrigue you
in your new to the channel lots of stuff in the backlog look at my playlists etc
and anyway will pop on the mirror put the tiles in and complete the room you
could see I also did the rug while I was at it with that same blue motif cuz the
that Rug really ties the room together a couple of card stock miniatures see
episode 9 for that anyway I do think the level of detail here is on par with
other major shops and so you know if you do the math please come out to a little
over a dollar per model for these 73 pieces and I do think that's worth it
you get a good variety there's no repeats of anything which
could be a positive or negative for you just depending what you're trying to do
but these are a useful shortcut so there's certain things with crafting
with doing found objects that we just can't quite get to the with the ultra
fine level of detail and these were an interesting experiment to see if that
such a shortcut would work so Mantic terrain crate check it out if you liked
this particular project here's two more that you should go check out right now
also enjoy this month's community showcase and don't forget to subscribe
and click that bell reminder icon I am why lock thanks for joining me and I'll
see you next time
